Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to advance the paradigm and constructability of building automation systems that improve earthquake-resilience of high-rise structures. The project can potentially improve citizen's safety by standardizing a smart seismic-controlling system for new high-rise developments to be placed in growing dense cities within highly-active seismic zones. By constructing buildings with modular seismic technology, the current expenses and risks of the real estate developer associated with the design and construction of these special structures in these locations can also be eliminated. Furthermore, expenses linked to catastrophic structural failures and on-going structural and non-structural repair can be prevented because of the autonomous and responsive nature of this project.

This I-Corps project frames a building automation system that control hazardous oscillations in high-rise buildings by mimicking the human FAP-behavior to manage its body postural balance after its quiet stance is disturbed. The proposed resilient performance of autonomous seismic control allows a minimization of structural and non-structural damage to the susceptible architecture by counteracting the loads in real-time. Our previous experiments with human participants subjected to lateral loads, and our past research on earthquake-resilient robotic structures for buildings has proven reliability of the technology to minimize the fundamental period of free vibration of a high-rise building threatened by major seismic motion. This I-Corps project can move the construction industry forward by challenging the motionless-based structural performance of current buildings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout the seven weeks the NSF-ICORPS program lasted, we interviewed 108 experts of the building industry exploring the potential for commercialization of the autonomous seismic-controlling system technology and all its features. Although at the beginning my team and I thought that real estate developers would be attracted to an autonomous building technology to improve their buildings disaster-resilience, our hypothesis was not aligned with their pains and gains. Active control technology in general, and specially autonomous technology has little potential for commercialization in the United States and Mexico in the near future, according to our interviews. Furthermore, disaster-resilience and safety is not a major concern among the industry experts as long as they comply with the minimum required standards. However, the rest of the features of our system were very compelling for both the structural engineer and the developer of essential facilities in highly active seismic zones.

Our findings basically point that, regardless of the location’s hazards, the issues concerning the most to the decision makers of the building industry are those directly linked to initial costs and construction timeframe. Since developing essential facilities in seismic zones require enhanced performance that implies more time-consuming analysis, complex construction and installation logistics, tight schedules and highly skilled labor; the cost and timeframe become even more critical factors. Based on the developers and engineers answers to our questions, building automation systems will add more risks and uncertainty to the already risky business of developing in earthquake-prone areas. 

At the other hand, modular systems, simpler construction technologies and integrated solutions are highly desirable due to their potential to minimize the risks associated with the developer’s profit and schedule. We found that there is a customer’s need for the simplified, plug-and-play technology we have developed for our system. Since our technology can dramatically simplify and accelerate the erection of structural steelwork on site while reducing the need for specialized labor, we determined that there could be a scalable business opportunity.

One broader impact of our technology is helping real estate developers of essential facilities in seismic zones to simplify and accelerate the construction of their buildings without relying on highly skilled labor. This may also have significant economic impacts during construction. We found that this is a current need and, therefore, we believe there might be also an actual market for our technology for developers who do not build essential facilities or even in seismic zones.
